text.p: The following are the main stories from Monday morning's Austrian newspapers.
- Four out of ten Austrian youths under the age of 18 would cast their vote in elections, a new study shows. Only some 20 percent of them would not want to vote at all.
- Beleaguered Chancellor and Social Democrat party leader Franz Vranitzky says he will push for reforms at a party conference to be held within the coming four weeks.
- Doctors heavily criticise Health Minister Christa Krammer's plans to have specialist doctors on call only during nights and weekends at Austria's hospital.
- Vienna Social Democrats continue search for a coalition partner after losing absolute majority in the Austrian capital in last week's municipal elections.
- State-owned telecoms monopoly Post & Telekom Austria poised to give major telephone book printing order to one of its subsidiaries, Omnimedia, without calling for a public tender.
- Austrian firms get ready for increased trade with Bosnia, expected to pick up next year.
- Analysts see ATX index breaking through key support at 1,100 points this week.
- Social Democrats' chief whip Peter Kostelka promises to step up campaign for new jobs in attempt to turn around his party's sagging fortunes.
- Opinion poll shows a majority of Viennese would prefer a coalition of Social Democrats, Greens and Liberal Forum party for the Vienna state government.
- Austrian shopowners grudgingly agree to Economics Minister Johann Farnleitner's proposal for a reduction of overall opening hours to 60 hours a week from 66 hours currently.
- Finnish Amer group expects its Austrian unit Atomic, a maker of skis and other sporting goods, to turn in a profit next year.
